item.title: Rubio Says Venezuela Will Submit Monthly Budget to White House
item.description: Democrats sharply questioned the plan, including the role of Qatar in managing an account funded by the sale of Venezuelan oil.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio testified before the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations during a hearing to examine U.S. policy towards Venezuela.

item.title: Why the NORAD Cold War Pact Between the U.S. and Canada Is News
item.description: The State Department clarified comments made by the U.S. Ambassador to Canada that NORAD would be “altered” if that country did not purchase American F-35 jets.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Center for Strategic and International Studies
item.media:description: Canada began a review of its agreement to buy F-35 fighter jets from the United States last year. The United States still wants Canada to use those jets for the common defense of North American airspace.

item.title: Plane Carrying Colombian Politicians Crashes in Area Contested by Rebels
item.description: The aircraft was carrying 15 people, and the authorities said there were no survivors.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.media:description: The aircraft that crashed was a Beechcraft 1900, similar to this one.

item.title: Dutch Court Orders Netherlands to Protect Bonaire From Climate Change
item.description: Bonaire, a Dutch overseas territory, deserves the same protections as Europe, the ruling said. The decision adds to a growing body of precedent worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Marieke Vellekoop, director of Greenpeace Netherlands, center, with plaintiffs from Bonaire in court in The Hague in October.

item.title: How Computer Warfare Is Becoming Part of the Pentagon’s Arsenal
item.description: The military tested a new approach in Venezuela and during strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Adam Sella
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The United States took power off-line in Caracas, Venezuela, to help military forces capture former President Nicolás Maduro this month.

item.title: Trinidadian Families File Wrongful Death Lawsuit Over Boat Strike by U.S. Military
item.description: The case tests the Trump administration’s argument that its extrajudicial killings of people suspected of smuggling drugs at sea have been lawful.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:description: A memorial held by family members of Chad Joseph, one of two Trinidadian men whom the U.S. military apparently killed in a boat strike in the fall, in Las Cuevas, Trinidad and Tobago, in October.

item.title: Canada’s Marineland Whales Could Find New Homes in U.S.
item.description: Marineland, a closed aquatic park in Ontario, had threatened to euthanize its whales after the government denied an application to send them to China.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Beluga whales in November at the now-closed Arctic Cove exhibit at Marineland, in Niagara Falls, Canada.

item.title: On Venezuela and Greenland, Many Trump Fans Give Him the Benefit of the Doubt
item.description: At least so far, President Trump has managed to bring along even those conservative supporters who are skeptical of foreign interventions.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A meeting of the Turning Point USA chapter last week at the University of Idaho in Moscow, Idaho.

item.title: In Venezuela, Freeing the Economy, but Nothing Else
item.description: Interim leader Delcy Rodríguez is liberalizing the economy without dismantling her predecessor’s repressive apparatus, raising questions about her aims.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Morning commuters in Caracas earlier this month.

item.title: Gunmen Kill 11 After Soccer Match in Mexico
item.description: The mass shooting occurred in an area fought over by drug cartels, just as the Mexican government has sought to show Washington that it is combating criminal groups.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Mexican National Guard members at the scene where 11 people were killed in Salamanca, Mexico, on Sunday.

item.title: Winter Storm Pummels Toronto With Record Snowfall
item.description: Canada’s biggest city got roughly 22 inches, and giant snow banks are unlikely to melt soon because of colder than usual temperatures.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Toronto on Monday. The city had a record-breaking 22 inches of snow.

item.title: In Venezuela, Families Search for Relatives Who Are Detained and Missing
item.description: Even as dozens of political prisoners have been freed, at least 66 people taken by state authorities and never heard from again remain missing, relatives and rights groups say.
item.dc:creator: Camille Rodríguez Montilla, Frances Robles and The New York Times
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: How Two Hardy North Dakotans Were Almost Thwarted by an Ice Storm
item.description: Jackie Gaddie and Craig Pietruszewski had been anticipating the trip of a lifetime, to Antarctica of all places. Then, a storm got in the way.
item.dc:creator: Sean Keenan
item.media:credit: Sean Keenan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Travelers waiting at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport on Saturday. A winter storm was causing flight disruptions in the region.

item.title: Beatriz González, Who Chronicled Colombia’s Turmoil in Paint, Dies at 93
item.description: Often drawing from reproduced images or newspaper photos, she made work that quietly yet memorably critiqued her country’s social and political order.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Ms. González in 2016. Her father “taught me to look at the landscape, from the mountain ranges to the streams flowing from the Magdalena River,” she said, while her mother “helped to train my eye.”

item.title: Trump Threatens Canada With Tariffs as Post-Davos Fallout Continues
item.description: President Trump said he would impose tariffs if Canada made “a deal with China,” though there is no sign that those countries are discussing a broad trade agreement.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump on the South Lawn of the White House on Thursday, after returning from the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

item.title: Mark Carney Takes On Donald Trump and Emerges as a Global Political Star
item.description: At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, the prime minister was praised for his blunt talk about the president’s irrevocable “rupture” in the world order.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Sean Kilpatrick/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney received a standing ovation for his speech at the World Economic Forum.

item.title: Despite Trump’s Words, China and Russia Are Not Threatening Greenland
item.description: U.S. and European officials say they are unaware of any intelligence that shows China and Russia are endangering the island, which is protected by the NATO security umbrella.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Trump has repeatedly cited security as his rationale for wanting to acquire Greenland.

item.title: How a Water Balloon Fight in Venezuela Ended in Charges of Treason
item.description: Venezuela’s interim government has been praised by President Trump. It has also maintained its state security apparatus to stamp out any perceived dissent.
item.dc:creator: Tibisay Romero, Jack Nicas, Patricia Sulbarán and The New York Times
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A 17-year-old boy who was one of 25 people detained in Barcelona, Venezuela, days after President Nicolás Maduro was captured.

item.title: U.S. Automakers’ Foreign Troubles Now Extend to Canada
item.description: U.S. trade policy has devastated the Canadian auto industry and pushed the country to reach an agreement that will make it easier for Chinese companies to sell cars there.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.category: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Canada could serve as an important test market for Chinese automakers, like Geely, which is producing vehicles at a plant in Hangzhou, China.

item.title: Joint Chiefs Chairman Issues Rare Invitation to Foreign Military Heads
item.description: Top military leaders from 34 countries plan to discuss improving efforts in the Western Hemisphere to fight drug trafficking and transnational criminal organizations.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gen. Dan Caine’s meeting comes at a fraught time for Washington’s relations with its immediate neighbors as well as allies in Europe.

item.title: Extreme Cold Sweeps Canada, With Manitoba and Saskatchewan Among the Worst Hit
item.description: The lowest temperatures are expected in southern Saskatchewan and southern Manitoba.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff

item.title: Under Pressure from Trump, Venezuela Agrees to Accept More U.S. Deportation Flights
item.description: Venezuela’s interim government, in another sign of its willingness to placate the Trump administration, is receiving more deportation flights. Three flights arrived this week.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: A deportation flight from the United States arriving at Simón Bolívar International Airport in Venezuela on Thursday.

item.title: Ryan Wedding, Canadian Ex-Snowboarder Accused of Running Drug Ring, Is Arrested
item.description: Ryan Wedding, 44, who competed in snowboarding in the 2002 Winter Olympics, has been charged with murder and smuggling cocaine into the United States.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Ryan Wedding, a former Olympic snowboarder, has been charged with smuggling cocaine into the United States and with murder.

item.title: Peru’s President May Be Ousted Over Secret Meetings with Chinese Businessmen
item.description: Leaked videos have prompted a scandal involving President José Jerí and two Chinese men under investigation.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Mitra Taj
item.media:description: President José Jerí of Peru arrives at Congress to speak to lawmakers in Lima, Peru, on Wednesday amid a scandal over undisclosed meetings with a Chinese businessman.

item.title: Trump Withdraws Carney’s Invitation for Canada to Join His ‘Board of Peace’
item.description: The president appeared to be lashing out in response to stark, high-profile remarks by Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada that rejected Mr. Trump’s efforts to dismantle the international order.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

item.title: Pushing Back on Trump, Carney Says ‘Canada Doesn’t Live Because of the United States’
item.description: The Canadian prime minister spoke after returning from the World Economic Forum where he urged middle powers to team up in resisting President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada at a news conference in Quebec City on Thursday.

item.title: Venezuela’s Edmundo González Said His Son-in-Law Was Freed From Detention
item.description: Edmundo González, seen by many as the real winner of Venezuela’s 2024 election, said his son-in-law was released after more than a year in detention.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Mariana González de Tudares, right, daughter of the former Venezuelan presidential candidate Edmundo González, waiting this month outside a detention center in Caracas, Venezuela.

item.title: Tânia Maria Is Brazil’s Newest Film Icon
item.description: Clad in florals and puffing on a cigarette, Tânia Maria has captivated audiences with a striking, if brief, performance in “The Secret Agent,” Brazil’s latest Oscar nominee.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tânia Maria, with Wagner Moura in a scene from “The Secret Agent,” has drawn praise from international critics.
